name: Roman Mythology
tagline: The Gods of Rome and Imperial Destiny
description: Explore Roman mythology where Greek gods received Latin names and new Roman character, and where destiny shaped the eternal empire.
overview: Roman mythology adapted and transformed Greek myths while maintaining distinctly Roman religious practices and values. The Romans identified their indigenous deities with Greek counterparts (Jupiter-Zeus, Mars-Ares, Venus-Aphrodite) but emphasized different aspects - Mars became more honorable as Rome's father-god, while practical deities of household, agriculture, and state were uniquely important. Roman religion focused on: precise ritual correctness (cultus deorum), state religion supporting imperial power, household gods (Lares and Penates), augury and divination, apotheosis of emperors, and the concept of pietas (duty to gods, family, and state). The Aeneid by Virgil established Rome's divine destiny as ordained by fate.

culturalContext.primarySources: Virgil's Aeneid, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Livy's History

sections.title: The Capitoline Triad
sections.body:
**Jupiter (Greek Zeus):** King of gods, sky, thunder. Patron of Roman state.
**Juno (Greek Hera):** Queen of gods, marriage, women. Protector of Rome.
**Minerva (Greek Athena):** Wisdom, warfare, crafts. Patron of arts and strategy.

These three were worshipped together in the Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus on the Capitoline Hill, the religious center of Rome.

sections.title: Rome's Foundation: Romulus & Remus
sections.body: Twin sons of Mars and Vesta priestess Rhea Silvia, abandoned as infants and suckled by a she-wolf. Founded Rome (753 BCE) after Romulus killed Remus in a dispute. Romulus became first king, later deified as Quirinus.

sections.title: Aeneas & Rome's Divine Destiny
sections.body: Aeneas, Trojan hero and son of Venus, survived Troy's fall and traveled to Italy carrying his father and household gods. Founded the Latin people, ancestors of Romans. Virgil's Aeneid establishes Rome's destined greatness as fulfillment of divine will, connecting Rome to Troy's glory.
